revision.text:
{{Infobox brand | name=truth | logo=truthlogo.jpg | producttype = Youth smoking prevention public education campaign | currentowner = [[Truth Initiative]] | introduced = 1998 | markets = United States | website = [https://www.thetruth.com thetruth.com] }}
'''Truth''' (stylized as '''truth''') is a national campaign aimed at eliminating teen smoking in the [[United States]]. "truth" produces television and digital content to encourage teens to reject tobacco and to unite against the tobacco industry. When "truth" launched its campaign in 1998, the teen smoking rate was 23%. In 2017, that number was down to 2.1% of middle schoolers and 7.6% of high schoolers,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/data_statistics/fact_sheets/youth_data/tobacco_use/index.htm|title=CDC - Fact Sheet - Youth and Tobacco Use - Smoking & Tobacco Use|last=Health|first=CDC's Office on Smoking and|date=2018-09-21|website=Smoking and Tobacco Use|language=en-us|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> partly due to the "truth" campaign.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/to-your-health/wp/2017/06/15/teenagers-tobacco-use-hits-a-record-low-with-a-sharp-drop-in-e-cigarettes/|title=Teenagers’ tobacco use hits a record low, with a sharp drop in e-cigarettes|last=McGinley|first=Laura|date=15 June 2017|website=Washington Post|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=15 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Evans WD, Rath JM, Hair EC, Snider JW, Pitzer L, Greenberg M, Xiao H, Cantrell J, Vallone D | display-authors = 6 | title = truth FinishIt brand on tobacco outcomes | journal = Preventive Medicine Reports | volume = 9 | pages = 6–11 | date = March 2018 | pmid = 29276667 | pmc = 5724797 | doi = 10.1016/j.pmedr.2017.11.008 }}</ref> In August 2014, "truth" launched "Finish It", a redesigned campaign encouraging youth to be the generation that ends smoking.<ref name="NYT Finish It">{{cite news|last1=Newman|first1=Andrew Adam |title=A Less Defiant Tack in a Campaign to Curb Smoking by Teenagers |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/11/business/a-less-defiant-tack-in-a-campaign-to-curb-smoking-by-teenagers-.html |accessdate=10 December 2014|work=The New York Times|date=10 August 2014}}</ref>
==History==
===Florida Tobacco Pilot Program===
The "truth" campaign was modeled after a campaign developed by the Florida Tobacco Pilot Program, which ran from 1998 to 2003.
Through their marketing campaign, the program set out to drive a wedge between the tobacco industry's advertising and a youth audience.<ref name="FloridaTruth">{{cite web|url=http://www.social-marketing.org/success/cs-floridatruth.html |title=Social Marketing Institute - Success Stories - Florida "truth" Campaign |publisher=Social-marketing.org |date=1997-08-25 |accessdate=2010-08-24}}</ref> The program not only assembled a team of advertising and public relations firms, but also collaborated with Floridian youth to develop a campaign that would effectively speak to their generation.<ref name="NCI Monograph 19">{{cite book|url=http://cancercontrol.cancer.gov/Brp/tcrb/monographs/19/index.html|title=The Role of the Media in Promoting and Reducing Tobacco Use: Tobacco Control Monograph No. 19|last1=National Cancer Institute|date=June 2008|publisher=U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, National Institutes of Health, National Cancer Institute|location=Bethesda, MD}}</ref><ref name=FloridaTruth /> Youth articulated their frustrations with the manipulative marketing tactics used by the tobacco industry, and described their ideal campaign as one that would give them facts and the truth about tobacco.<ref name="NCI Monograph 19" /> From this emerged the concept of uniting youth in a movement against tobacco companies promoted through grassroots advocacy and a youth-driven advertising campaign.<ref name=FloridaTruth />
In March 1998, student delegates at a meeting sponsored by Florida's Office of Tobacco Control voted to change the theme of the campaign to "truth, a generation united against tobacco."<ref name="FloridaTruth" /> In April 1998, Florida launched a $25 million advertising campaign that included 33 television commercials, seven billboards, eight print ads and four posters.<ref name="FloridaTruth" /> With a target audience of youth aged 12–17, the Florida "truth" campaign modeled their approach after commercial marketing to teens, and used messages that "attacked the [tobacco] industry and portrayed its executives as predatory, profit hungry, and manipulative."<ref name="NCI Monograph 19" /> The ads re-framed tobacco as an addictive drug promoted by the adult-establishment, and tobacco control as a hip, rebellious, youth-led movement.<ref name=FloridaTruth /> The grassroots effort of the campaign involved real teenagers taking on the tobacco industry as part of the 13-day "Truth Train" tour across the state.<ref name="NCI Monograph 19" /> Despite positive results, reduced funding for the program, among other factors, ultimately led to the demise of Florida’s "truth" campaign.<ref name="NCI Monograph 19" />
===Truth Initiative "truth" campaign===
As Florida’s campaign diminished, [[Truth Initiative]] (originally the American Legacy Foundation), adopted Florida's successful strategy and converted "truth" into a national campaign. Generally consistent with Florida's campaign, Truth Initiative's version of "truth" featured hard-hitting messages highlighting the deceptive practices of tobacco companies, and stark facts about the deadly effects of tobacco.<ref name="NCI Monograph 19" />
==Campaign strategy and style==
"truth" strives to be a brand youth can identify with. In stark contrast to the heavy "life or death" tone adopted by many anti-tobacco campaigns, the strategy behind "truth" is to emphasize the facts about tobacco products and industry marketing practices, without preaching or talking down to its target audience.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cancercontrol.cancer.gov/Brp/tcrb/monographs/19/index.html|title=National Cancer Institute - Cancer Control and Population Sciences|website=cancercontrol.cancer.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref> The resonating theme underlying "truth" is one of tobacco industry manipulation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iom.edu/Reports/2007/Ending-the-Tobacco-Problem-A-Blueprint-for-the-Nation.aspx|title=Ending the Tobacco problem: A Blueprint for the Nation|last=|first=|date=23 May 2007|website=Institute of Medicine|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091021204700/http://www.iom.edu/Reports/2007/Ending-the-Tobacco-Problem-A-Blueprint-for-the-Nation.aspx|archive-date=2009-10-21|dead-url=yes|access-date=15 November 2017}}</ref> With hard-hitting advertisements featuring youths confronting the tobacco industry, "truth" built a brand focused on empowering youth to construct positive, tobacco-free identities. Above all, the campaign avoids making directive statements telling youth not to smoke, and instead encourages them to make up their own minds about smoking and the tobacco industry.<ref name="NCI Monograph 19" /><ref name="Health Promotion Chapter 10">{{cite book|url=http://samples.jbpub.com/9780763753771/53771_CH10_FINAL.pdf|title=The truth Campaign: Using Countermarketing to Reduce Youth Smoking|last1=Allen|first1=Jane|last2=Vallone|first2=Donna|last3=Vargyas|first3=Ellen|last4=Healton|first4=Cheryl|date=2010|publisher=Jones and Bartlett Publishers|pages=195–215}}</ref> "truth" channels youths’ rebellious nature and need to assert their independence towards tobacco control efforts.<ref name="Farrelly">{{cite journal|last1=Farrelly|first1=M.|last2=Healton|first2=C.|last3=Davis|first3=K.|last4=Messeri|first4=P.|last5=Hersey|first5=J.|last6=Haviland|first6=M.|date=June 2002|title=Getting to the Truth: Evaluating National Tobacco Countermarketing Campaigns|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=92|issue=6|pages=901–907|doi=10.2105/ajph.92.6.901|pmc=1447480|pmid=12036775}}</ref>
In addition to exposing industry marketing practices, many of the advertisements produced for "truth" focus on facts about the ingredients in cigarettes and the consequences of smoking, including addiction, disease, and death.<ref name="Health Promotion Chapter 10" /> A large portion of the facts and information exposed in "truth" advertisements were pulled from real tobacco industry documents that were made publicly accessible following the [[Tobacco Master Settlement Agreement|Master Settlement Agreement]]. The [[Truth Tobacco Industry Documents|Truth Tobacco Documents Library]], created in 2002 and managed by the [[University of California, San Francisco|University of California San Francisco]], houses millions of formerly secret tobacco industry internal corporate documents.
=== Initial tactics and campaigns === The "truth campaign's initial objective was to "change social norms and reduce youth smoking."<ref>{{Cite web|URL=httpd://www.legacyforhealth.org/content/download/621/7337/file/truth_fact_sheet_January_2012.PDF|title=truth Face Sheet|last=|first=|date=12 December 2014|website=American Legacy Foundation|access-date=15 November 2017}}</ref> In building a strategy to accomplish this goal, "truth" campaign designers looked to marketing and social science research, evidence from other successful campaigns, and engaged in conversations with teen audiences. This research revealed that although youth were aware of the deadly nature of cigarettes, they were attracted to smoking as a tool for rebellion and empowerment. The "truth" campaign designers wanted to counter the appeal of cigarettes by encouraging teens to rebel against the duplicity and manipulation exhibited by tobacco companies.<ref name="NCI Monograph 19" />
Since the launch of "truth" in 2000, the campaign asserts it has "utilized many different forms of media and evolved its tactics to ensure it reached the teen audience most effectively."<ref name="truth Fact Sheet 2012">{{cite web |url= http://www.legacyforhealth.org/content/download/621/7337/file/truth_fact_sheet_January_2012.PDF |title=truth Fact Sheet |last1=American Legacy Foundation |date=January 2012 |website= Legacy |accessdate= 12 December 2014}}</ref>
Arguably the most recognized media produced for "truth" are its television advertisements. For example, the iconic "truth" advertisement "1200" portrays a mass of youth walking up to a major tobacco company building, then suddenly collapsing as if dead while a single youth remains standing with a sign that reads, "Tobacco kills 1,200 people a day. Ever think about taking a day off?"<ref>{{cite web|title=1200|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gJTCWtcAews|website=YouTube|accessdate=17 December 2014}}</ref> In the "Body Bags" commercial, youths pile body bags on the sidewalk outside of a tobacco company's headquarters. One youth steps forward with a megaphone to shout up at the workers in the building, "do you know how many people tobacco kills every day? This is what 1200 people actually looks like."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c4xmFcrJexk|title=The Truth - Body Bags Tv Ad|website=YouTube|accessdate=13 December 2014}}</ref> Another "truth" advertisement, "Singing Cowboy", portrays a cowboy who has a breathing stoma (opening) in his neck singing, "you don’t always die from tobacco, sometimes you just lose a lung", and other similar lyrics.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LP6vMbkx2hw|title=ugly truth: Singing Cowboy|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=13 December 2014}}</ref> A third commercial, "1 out of 3", uses "fantasized scenes such as an exploding soda can" to convey the message that tobacco is the only product that prematurely kills one out of three users.<ref name="NCI Monograph 19" /> Perhaps one of truth's best-known campaigns, "Shards O' Glass," aired during [[Super Bowl XXXVII]]. The commercial showed an executive for a popsicle company, "Shards O' Glass," that provided disclaimers for their product - a popsicle with shards of glass in it, clearly unsafe and deadly - and posed the question, "What if all companies advertised like big tobacco?"
Through social media feedback and focus group testing, "truth" designers learned teens respond best to "up-front and powerful messages that display courage and honesty in a forceful way."<ref name="truth Fact Sheet 2012" /> With that in mind, other edgy "truth" advertisements with various themes were produced between 2000 and 2014, including "Connect truth", "The Sunny Side of truth", "Unsweetened truth", and "Ugly truth."
Prior to the launch of the [[Food and Drug Administration|Food and Drug Administration’s]] "Real Cost" campaign in February 2014, "truth" was the only national youth tobacco prevention campaign not sponsored by the tobacco industry.<ref name="Health Promotion Chapter 10" />
=== Campaign re-launch strategy and examples === In August 2014, "truth" launched the "Finish It" campaign targeting the next generation of U.S. youth aged 15 to 21.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CNS0JaX9_X8|title=truth - Finishers|last=|first=|date=|website=www.youtube.com|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140811231135/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CNS0JaX9_X8|archive-date=2014-08-11|dead-url=yes|access-date=2015-11-16}}</ref> Along with a revamped campaign design, web presence, and series of ads, Finish It embraces a powerful new campaign theme: be the generation that ends smoking for good.<ref name="NYT Finish It" /> In research with its target audience, campaign designers discovered today’s teenagers are less interested in protesting against tobacco industry manipulation, and more interested in driving positive collective action. "Finish IT" was developed to suit this generation’s desire to be agents of social change.<ref name="NYT Finish It" /> The campaign aims to empower the 94 percent of teenage nonsmokers, and the 6 percent of teen smokers, to take an active role in ending the tobacco epidemic.<ref name="Tobacco-Free Kids">{{cite news|url=http://www.tobaccofreekids.org/press_releases/post/2014_08_12_truth_campaign|title=Reinvigorated truth® Campaign Will Empower Youth to Finish the Fight against Tobacco|last1=Myers|first1=Matthew|date=12 August 2014|accessdate=15 December 2014|agency=Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids}}</ref>
The first campaign ad released, "Finishers", was shot in the style of a video manifesto and tells youth, "We have the power. We have the creativity. We will be the generation that ends smoking. Finish it."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CNS0JaX9_X8|title=truth - Finishers|last1=truthorange|accessdate=14 December 2014}}</ref> The spot encouraged youth to get involved in the "Finish IT" movement by superimposing the campaign logo, an "X" in an orange square, onto their [[Facebook]] profile picture. This online activism tactic is similar to that used by the [[Human Rights Campaign]] when they asked individuals to change their profile pictures in support of [[Same-sex marriage|marriage equality]].<ref name="NYT Finish It" />
In another series of "Finish IT" ads, "Unpaid Tobacco Spokesperson" and "Unpaid Tobacco Spokesperson Response", the campaign tries to shed light on the way smokers, especially celebrity smokers, give tobacco companies free marketing as "unpaid spokespeople" when their photos are posted.<ref name="youtube.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DaLjUAj_54s|title=truth - Unpaid Tobacco Spokesperson Response|last1=truthorange|accessdate=14 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uTj4I9WUggw|title=truth - Unpaid Tobacco Spokesperson|last1=truthorange|accessdate=14 December 2014}}</ref> As a response, Finish It asked youth to "think before you post a smoking selfie."<ref name="youtube.com" /> The campaign also encouraged youth to "erase and replace" cigarettes from photos on social media with various props from the "truth" website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thetruth.com/take-action|title=Take Action|last1=truth|accessdate=14 December 2014}}</ref>
In 2015, "Left Swipe Dat," a full-length song and music video created as part of the "Finish IT" campaign, debuted at the [[57th Annual Grammy Awards]] and connected smoking to dating. The video featured [[Becky G]], [[Fifth Harmony]], [[King Bach]] and other influencers. The lyrics revealed that you get half the matches on dating apps if you're smoking in your profile picture. "Left Swipe Dat" encouraged teens to lose the cigarettes so they could avoid being "left swiped," aka, passed over on a dating app.
In another effort to connect smoking to a teen passion point, "CATmageddon" showed teens that smoking is bad for pets and set up the scenario that if there were no cats (due to smoking-related illness and disease) there would be no [[Cats and the Internet|cat videos]] and therefore there would be a "CATmageddon," a "world devoid of furry kittens and the adorable, hilarious videos that come with them." The ad launched at the [[58th Annual Grammy Awards]] and featured partnerships with [[Petco]], [[Adult Swim]], and [[BuzzFeed]].
In 2017, the "truth" campaign showed how the tobacco industry has targeted African-Americans, low-income communities, LGBTQ individuals, members of the military as well as those with mental health conditions.<ref name="Kulp">{{Cite news|url=http://mashable.com/2017/02/12/tobacco-ads-target-diversity/|title=A new anti-smoking ad slams Big Tobacco for targeting black neighborhoods|last=Kulp|first=Patrick|work=Mashable|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/new-ads-accuse-big-tobacco-of-targeting-soldiers-and-people-with-mental-illness/2017/08/23/02bff930-8843-11e7-a50f-e0d4e6ec070a_story.html|title=New ads accuse Big Tobacco of targeting soldiers and people with mental illness|last=Wan|first=William|date=2017-08-24|work=Washington Post|access-date=2017-08-16|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> The campaign encouraged young people to take note of the industry's advertising tactics while educating teens on the tobacco-related health disparities across these demographics. Initial documentary style videos created for this campaign featured comedian and actress [[Amanda Seales]] and premiered at the [[59th Annual Grammy Awards]].<ref name="Kulp"/> Later videos, premiered at the [[2017 MTV Video Music Awards]] and featured journalists [[Kaj Larsen]] and [[Ryan Duffy (journalist)|Ryan Duffy]], as well as rapper [[Logic (musician)|Logic]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/new-ads-accuse-big-tobacco-of-targeting-soldiers-and-people-with-mental-illness/2017/08/23/02bff930-8843-11e7-a50f-e0d4e6ec070a_story.html|title=New ads accuse Big Tobacco of targeting soldiers and people with mental illness|last=Wan|first=William|date=2017-08-24|work=Washington Post|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
In 2018, "truth" launched anti-vaping campaign ads showing the dangers of vaping for the first time.<ref>https://www.thetruth.com/articles/hot-topic/safer-safe</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.healthline.com/health-news/will-e-cigarettes-reverse-the-decline-in-teen-smoking#The-concern-about-Juul|title=E-Cigarettes and Teen Smoking|work=Healthline|access-date=2018-10-26|language=en}}</ref>
=== Grassroots tours === In addition to its television advertisements, "truth" maintains an online presence and employs [[Guerrilla marketing|guerrilla "on-the-street" marketing]]. Grassroots marketing is done via a team of "truth tour riders" who are sent to popular music and sporting events across the country every summer, including [[Warped Tour]], [[Mayhem Festival]] and High School Nation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://college.usatoday.com/2015/07/22/truth-anti-smoking-organization-launces-summer-tour-finish-it/|title=Anti-smoking organization launches tour to end teen tobacco use|date=2015-07-22|work=USA TODAY College|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Merchandise === "truth" also produces a line of custom merchandise every summer that is distributed at events. Each piece of merchandise features a design that corresponds with a fact about smoking. Items are often created in partnership with artists, such as a pair of custom sneakers made in collaboration with Kevin Lyons and [[Vans]] shoes. That partnership also spawned a contest called "Custom Culture" where students competed in design challenges relevant to the campaign's merchandise and subject matter.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vans.com/article_detail/custom-culture-2015.html|title=Vans Kicks Off the Sixth Annual Custom Culture Art Competition|website=Vans USA - English|language=en|access-date=2017-11-17}}</ref>
==Evaluation and effectiveness==
Rigorous evaluation studies of "truth" have been published in the peer-reviewed literature since the launch of the campaign in 2000.<ref name="Health Promotion Chapter 10" /> To evaluate the effectiveness of "truth", Truth Initiative employs an internal Research and Evaluation team.<ref>{{cite web|last1=American Legacy Foundation|title=Examining tobacco use among youth and young adults|url=http://www.legacyforhealth.org/what-we-do/tobacco-control-research/research-evaluation/examining-tobacco-use-among-youth-and-young-adults|website=Legacy|accessdate=13 December 2014}}</ref> Its efforts include evaluation of televised truth ads as well as digital, gaming and grassroots campaign components. Between 1999 and 2004, Truth Initiative (known at the time as the American Legacy Foundation) conducted a nationally-representative Media Tracking Survey of youth aged 12–17 to inform its "truth" campaign evaluation. The Legacy Media Tracking Survey (LMTS) measured tobacco-related attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors, exposure to smoking influences including "truth", sensation seeking, and openness to smoking.<ref name="Health Promotion Chapter 10" />
Cross-sectional studies on the effectiveness of the "truth" campaign provided convincing evidence that the campaign "had a significant impact on tobacco industry-related attitudes, beliefs, and other behavioral precursors, as well as a significant impact on youth smoking prevalence in the United States."<ref name="NCI Monograph 19" /> Exposure to "truth" was also associated with a statistically significant reduction in nonsmokers’ intentions to smoke in the future. Another study of "truth" from 2000 to 2004 examined whether campaign awareness and receptivity differed for youth across socioeconomic backgrounds. In 2005, a study published in the [[American Journal of Public Health]] conducted by [[RTI International]], [[Columbia University]], and Truth Initiative used a pre/post quasi-experimental design to relate changes in national youth smoking prevalence to exposure to the "truth" campaign over time.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cancercontrol.cancer.gov/Brp/tcrb/monographs/19/index.html|title=The Role of the Media in Promoting and Reducing Tobacco Use: Tobacco Control Monograph, No. 19|last=National Cancer Institute|first=|date=|website=cancercontrol.cancer.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-11-17}}</ref> The study’s statistical analyses showed that smoking rates among youth in the U.S. declined at a faster rate after the launch of the "truth" campaign. A similar study published in the [[American Journal of Preventive Medicine]] in 2009 found a direct association between youth exposure to "truth" messaging and a decreased risk of taking up smoking.
A 2009 study examined whether the $324 million investment in the "truth" campaign could be justified by its effect on public health outcomes. Researchers found that the campaign was economically efficient because it saved between $1.9 and $5.4 billion in medical care costs to society between 2000-2002. In this way, the authors argue "truth" is a cost-effective public health intervention.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Holtgrave, D.; Wunderink, K.; Vallone, D.; Healton, C.|first=|date=2009|title=Cost-Utility Analysis of the National truth Campaign to Prevent Youth Smoking|url=http://www.ajpmonline.org/article/S0749-3797%2809%2900075-0/pdf|journal=American Journal of Preventive Medicine|volume=36|pages=385–388|via=|doi=10.1016/j.amepre.2009.01.020}}</ref>
A study evaluating the "Finish IT" campaign indicated lower intentions to smoke in the next year as well as anti-tobacco attitudes with higher ad awareness.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Vallone|first=Vallone|last2=Cantrell|first2=Cantrell|last3=Bennett|first3=Bennett|last4=Smith|first4=Smith|last5=Rath|first5=Jessica|last6=Xiao|first6=Xiao|last7=Greenberg|first7=Greenberg|last8=Hair|first8=Elizabeth C.|date=2017-06-02|title=Evidence of the Impact of the truth FinishIt Campaign|journal=Nicotine & Tobacco Research: Official Journal of the Society for Research on Nicotine and Tobacco|doi=10.1093/ntr/ntx119|issn=1469-994X|pmid=28575421}}</ref> Ad recall remained high, even when the campaign aired lower levels of television targeted rating points as compared with earlier "truth" advertising campaigns.
== Awards and praise == The "truth" campaign has been praised by a number of leading federal and state public health officials,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/502009|title=Anti-Smoking Campaign Lowers Youth Smoking Rates With"Truth" Funding Threatened|last1=Krisberg|first1=Kim|date=2005|accessdate=14 December 2014|publisher=Nations Health|issue=35}}</ref> as well as the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]],<ref>{{cite book|url=https://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/stateandcommunity/counter_marketing/manual/pdfs/tobacco_cm_manual.pdf|title=Designing and Implementing an Effective Tobacco Counter-Marketing Campaign|last1=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|date=October 2003|publisher=U.S. Department of Health and Human Services|location=Atlanta, Georgia|accessdate=14 December 2014}}</ref> and the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services|U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://www.hhs.gov/ash/initiatives/tobacco/tobaccostrategicplan2010.pdf|title=Ending the Tobacco Epidemic: A Tobacco Control Strategic Action Plan for the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.|last1=U.S. Department of Health and Human Services|date=November 2010|publisher=Office of the Assistant Secretary for Health|location=Washington, DC|accessdate=14 December 2014}}</ref> The campaign has also been recognized for its achievements in marketing with numerous awards in advertising efficacy, such as [[Emmy Award|Emmy]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://emmyonline.com/psa_0506_winners|title=The National Television Academy Presents the Public and Community Service Emmy Awards|last=|first=|date=|website=National Academy of Television|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://64.13.227.18/emmy/2005_csa_psa_winners_release.html|title=Public & Community Service Awards - 2005 Winners|last=|first=|date=|website=Television National Academy|access-date=2017-11-22}}</ref> Clio Healthcare,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cliohealthcare.com/catalog/2013/film/|title=Winners 2013, Film|last=|first=|date=|work=CLIO Healthcare|access-date=2017-11-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131121041850/http://www.cliohealthcare.com/catalog/2013/film/|archive-date=2013-11-21|dead-url=yes|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cliohealthcare.com/catalog/2013/integrated_campaign/entry.cfm?entryid=401310051&award=50&from=1&to=500&order=0&direction=1|title=Winners 2013|last=|first=|date=|work=CLIO Healthcare|access-date=2017-11-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141206104512/http://www.cliohealthcare.com/catalog/2013/integrated_campaign/entry.cfm?entryid=401310051&award=50&from=1&to=500&order=0&direction=1|archive-date=2014-12-06|dead-url=yes|language=en-US}}</ref> and [[Effie Award|Effie]] awards.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://effie.org/case_studies/by_category/106|title=Youth Marketing North America Case Studies|last=|first=|date=|website=Effie Worldwide|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130920061744/http://www.effie.org/case_studies/by_category/106|archive-date=2013-09-20|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://current.effie.org/goodworks_effie|title=Woodworks Effie|last=|first=|date=|website=Effie Worldwide|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218024847/http://current.effie.org/goodworks_effie|archive-date=2014-12-18|dead-url=yes|access-date=22 November 2017|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising/truth-shares-grand-effie-award-64707|title='Truth' Shares Grand Effie Award|last=Griswold|first=Alice|date=|work=|access-date=2017-11-22|language=en-US}}</ref> "truth" has also been featured in a variety of academic marketing and communications textbooks to educate the next generation of public health and social marketing leaders.<ref name="truth Fact Sheet 2012" />
In 2014, Advertising Age named truth one of the top 10 ad campaigns on the 21st century.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://adage.com/lp/top15/#truth|title=Top 15 Ad Campaigns of the 21st Century - Advertising Age|last=Rodriguez|first=Ashley|date=|website=adage.com|access-date=2017-11-22}}</ref>
In 2016, the [[Monitoring the Future]] study, which surveys national samples of over 45,000 youth in grades 8, 10 and 12, reported historically low levels of current cigarette use amongst youth - only 6 percent of teens still smoke.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monitoringthefuture.org/pubs/monographs/mtf-overview2016.pdf|title=Monitoring the Future National Survey Results on Drug Use 1975-2016|last=Monitoring the Future website|first=|date=|website=|access-date=11 November 2017}}</ref>
==Litigation==
A "truth" campaign radio ad called "Dog Walker" prompted [[Lorillard Tobacco Company]] to pursue litigation against Truth Initiative (then the American Legacy Foundation). The dispute ran from July 2001 until its resolution in July 2006. In the ad, an actor who identified himself as a dog walker placed a phone call to Lorillard, offering to sell Lorillard the urine from his dogs.<ref name=autogenerated3>{{cite web|url=http://www.americanlegacy.org/190.html |title=Legacy Litigation | The American Legacy Foundation |publisher=Web.archive.org |date= |accessdate=2010-08-24 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071012071958/http://www.americanlegacy.org/190.html |archivedate = 2007-10-12}}</ref> The "truth" advertisement states urine and tobacco both contain [[urea]].<ref name=autogenerated3 />
Initially, Lorillard accused the ad agency of violating the laws regarding the taping of telephone conversations and threatened to refer them to the criminal authorities. In October 2001, Lorillard filed a [[Motion (legal)|Motion]] for a [[Declaratory Ruling]] with the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC), asking the FCC to rule that the radio stations’ broadcast of the ad violated an FCC regulation regarding broadcasting of telephone conversations.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.fcc.gov/Bureaus/Mass_Media/Public_Notices/da012565.doc |title=Mass Media Bureau Action Comment Sought On Motion For Declaratory Ruling |publisher=Federal Communications Commission |date=November 5, 2001 |accessdate=2010-08-24}}</ref> In November 2001, Lorillard notified Truth Initiative of their intent to litigate against the organization and its ad agency for defamation. Lorillard stated that it would not sue if the foundation agreed to a series of demands. Accordingly, Truth Initiative entered into discussions with Lorillard to attempt an out-of-court resolution. However, on January 18, 2002, Lorillard abandoned discussions and advanced a new claim that portions of the "truth" campaign violated the Master Settlement Agreement's prohibition against "vilification" or "personal attacks."<ref name=autogenerated3 />
Cases were filed in both [[Delaware]] and [[North Carolina]]. The matter was resolved by the [[Delaware Supreme Court]] on July 17, 2006. They ruled unanimously that the "truth" campaign did not violate the Master Settlement Agreement.<ref name=autogenerated3/>

{{redirect|Synthespian|the science fiction novel|Synthespians™|}} {{redirect-multi|2|Virtual girl|Virtual human}} A '''virtual human''' or '''digital clone''' is the creation or re-creation of a human being in image and voice using [[computer-generated imagery]] and sound, that is often indistinguishable from the real actor. This idea was first portrayed in the 1981 film ''[[Looker]]'', wherein models had their bodies scanned digitally to create 3D computer generated images of the models, and then animating said images for use in TV commercials. Two 1992 books used this concept: "Fools" by [[Pat Cadigan]], and ''Et Tu, Babe'' by [[Mark Leyner]].
In general, virtual humans employed in movies are known as '''synthespians''', '''virtual actors''', '''vactors''', '''cyberstars''', or '''"silicentric" actors'''. There are several legal ramifications for the digital cloning of human actors, relating to [[copyright]] and [[personality right]]s. People who have already been digitally cloned as simulations include [[Bill Clinton]], [[Marilyn Monroe]], [[Fred Astaire]], [[Ed Sullivan]], [[Elvis Presley]], [[Bruce Lee]], [[Audrey Hepburn]], [[Anna Marie Goddard]], and [[George Burns]]. Ironically, data sets of [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] for the creation of a virtual Arnold (head, at least) have already been made.<ref name=Landon>{{cite book|title=Edging Into the Future: Science Fiction and Contemporary Cultural Transformation|editor=Veronica Hollinger and Joan Gordon|author=Brooks Landon|chapter=Synthespians, Virtual Humans, and Hypermedia|pages=57–59|year=2002|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|isbn=0-8122-1804-3}}</ref><ref name=Creed>{{cite book|title=The Film Cultures Reader|editor=Graeme Turner|author=[[Barbara Creed]]|chapter=The Cyberstar|year=2002|publisher=Routledge|isbn=0-415-25281-4}}</ref>
The name "Schwarzeneggerization" comes from the 1992 book ''Et Tu, Babe'' by [[Mark Leyner]]. In one scene, on pages 50–51, a character asks the shop assistant at a video store to have Arnold Schwarzenegger digitally substituted for existing actors into various works, including (amongst others) ''[[Rain Man]]'' (to replace both [[Tom Cruise]] and [[Dustin Hoffman]]), ''[[My Fair Lady (film)|My Fair Lady]]'' (to replace [[Rex Harrison]]), ''[[Amadeus (film)|Amadeus]]'' (to replace [[F. Murray Abraham]]), ''[[The Diary of Anne Frank]]'' (as Anne Frank), ''[[Gandhi (film)|Gandhi]]'' (to replace [[Ben Kingsley]]), and ''[[It's a Wonderful Life]]'' (to replace [[James Stewart]]). Schwarzeneggerization is the name that Leyner gives to this process. Only 10 years later, Schwarzeneggerization was close to being reality.<ref name=Landon />
By 2002, Schwarzenegger, [[Jim Carrey]], [[Kate Mulgrew]], [[Michelle Pfeiffer]], [[Denzel Washington]], [[Gillian Anderson]], and [[David Duchovny]] had all had their heads [[3D scanning|laser scanned]] to create digital computer models thereof.<ref name=Landon />
== Early history == Early computer-generated animated faces include the 1985 film ''Tony de Peltrie'' and the [[music video]] for [[Mick Jagger]]'s song "Hard Woman" (from ''[[She's the Boss]]''). The first actual human beings to be digitally duplicated were [[Marilyn Monroe]] and [[Humphrey Bogart]] in a March 1987 film "[[Rendez-vous in Montreal]]" created by [[Nadia Magnenat Thalmann]] and [[Daniel Thalmann]] for the 100th anniversary of the [[Engineering Institute of Canada]]. The film was created by six people over a year, and had Monroe and Bogart meeting in a café in [[Montreal, Quebec]], Canada. The characters were rendered in three dimensions, and were capable of speaking, showing emotion, and shaking hands.<ref name=Thalmann>{{cite book|title=Handbook of Virtual Humans|author=Nadia Magnenat-Thalmann and Daniel Thalmann|pages=6–7|year=2004|publisher=John Wiley and Sons|isbn=0-470-02316-3}}</ref>
In 1987, the Kleiser-Walczak Construction Company (now Synthespian Studios), founded by Jeff Kleiser and [[Diana Walczak]] coined the term "synthespian" and began its Synthespian ("[[wikt:synthetic|synthetic]] [[wikt:thespian|thespian]]") Project, with the aim of creating "life-like figures based on the digital animation of clay models".<ref name=Creed /><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.synthespianstudios.net/about/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2014-07-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140511233900/http://www.synthespianstudios.net/about/ |archive-date=2014-05-11 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
In 1988, ''[[Tin Toy]]'' was the first entirely computer-generated movie to win an [[Academy Award]] ([[Academy Award for Animated Short Film|Best Animated Short Film]]). In the same year, Mike the Talking Head, an animated head whose facial expression and head posture were controlled in real time by a puppeteer using a custom-built controller, was developed by [[Silicon Graphics]], and performed live at [[SIGGRAPH]]. In 1989, ''[[The Abyss]]'', directed by [[James Cameron]] included a computer-generated face placed onto a watery pseudopod.<ref name=Thalmann /><ref name=Lester>{{cite book|title=Visual Communication: Images With Messages|author=Paul Martin Lester|pages=353|year=2005|publisher=Thomson Wadsworth|isbn=0-534-63720-5}}</ref>
In 1991, ''[[Terminator 2: Judgment Day]]'', also directed by Cameron, confident in the abilities of computer-generated effects from his experience with ''The Abyss'', included a mixture of synthetic actors with live animation, including computer models of [[Robert Patrick]]'s face. ''The Abyss'' contained just one scene with photo-realistic computer graphics. ''Terminator 2: Judgment Day'' contained over forty shots throughout the film.<ref name=Thalmann /><ref name=Lester /><ref>{{cite book|title=Visual Digital Culture: Surface Play and Spectacle in New Media Genres|author=Andrew Darley|chapter=The Waning of Narrative|pages=109|year=2000|publisher=Routledge|isbn=0-415-16554-7}}</ref>
In 1997, [[Industrial Light and Magic]] worked on creating a virtual actor that was a composite of the bodily parts of several real actors.<ref name=Creed />
By the 21st century, virtual actors had become a reality. The face of [[Brandon Lee]], who had died partway through the shooting of ''[[The Crow (1994 film)|The Crow]]'' in 1994, had been digitally superimposed over the top of a body-double in order to complete those parts of the movie that had yet to be filmed. By 2001, three-dimensional computer-generated realistic humans had been used in ''[[Final Fantasy: The Spirits Within]]'', and by 2004, a synthetic [[Laurence Olivier]] co-starred in ''[[Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow]]''.<ref name=Remshardt>{{cite book|title=Intermediality in Theatre and Performance|editor=Freda Chapple and Chiel Kattenbelt|author=Ralf Remshardt|chapter=The actor as imtermedialist: remetiation, appropriation, adaptation|pages=52–53|year=2006|publisher=Rodopi|isbn=90-420-1629-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Digital 3D Design|author=Simon Danaher|pages=38|year=2004|publisher=Thomson Course Technology|isbn=1-59200-391-5}}</ref>
The ''[[Star Wars]]'' Anthology film, ''[[Rogue One|Rogue One: a Star Wars story]]'' (2016) whose plot ends minutes before that of ''[[Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope]]'' (1977), digitally recreated the appearances of [[Peter Cushing]] in the role [[Grand Moff Tarkin]] (played and voiced by [[Guy Henry (actor)|Guy Henry]]), and [[Carrie Fisher]] as [[Princess Leia]] (played by [[Ingvild Deila]]. Fisher's only line was added using archival voice footage of Carrie Fisher saying the word "Hope".). The virtual versions replicated the characters' appearances as seen in the aforementioned ''Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope''. Cushing had died in 1994, while Fisher died a few days after the film's release. [[Industrial Light and Magic]] created the special effects, and noted that the technique would not be used often, noting also that the ''young [[Han Solo]] film'' would not use [[Harrison Ford]]'s likeness.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/27/movies/how-rogue-one-brought-back-grand-moff-tarkin.html</ref>
== Legal issues == Critics such as Stuart Klawans in the ''[[New York Times]]'' expressed worry about the loss of "the very thing that art was supposedly preserving: our point of contact with the irreplaceable, finite person". And even more problematic are the issues of copyright and personality rights. Actors have little legal control over a digital clone of themselves. In the United States, for instance, they must resort to database protection laws in order to exercise what control they have (The proposed [[Database and Collections of Information Misappropriation Act]] would strengthen such laws). An actor does not own the copyright on his digital clones, unless they were created by him. Robert Patrick, for example, would not have any legal control over the liquid metal digital clone of himself that was created for ''Terminator 2: Judgment Day''.<ref name=Remshardt /><ref>{{cite book|title=Cultural Control And Globalization in Asia: Copyright, Piracy, and Cinema|author=Laikwan Pang|chapter=Expressions, originality, and fixation|pages=20|year=2006|publisher=Routledge|isbn=0-415-35201-0}}</ref>
The use of digital clones in movie industry, to replicate the acting performances of a cloned person, represents a controversial aspect of these implications, as it may cause real actors to land in fewer roles, and put them in disadvantage at contract negotiations, since a clone could always be used by the producers at potentially lower costs. It is also a career difficulty, since a clone could be used in roles that a real actor would never accept for various reasons. Bad identifications of an actor's image with a certain type of roles could harm his career, and real actors, conscious of this, pick and choose what roles they play ([[Bela Lugosi]] and [[Margaret Hamilton (actress)|Margaret Hamilton]] became [[Typecasting (acting)|typecast]] with their roles as [[Count Dracula]] and the [[Wicked Witch of the West]], whereas [[Anthony Hopkins]] and [[Dustin Hoffman]] have played a diverse range of parts). A digital clone could be used to play the parts of (for examples) an axe murderer or a prostitute, which would affect the actor's public image, and in turn affect what future casting opportunities were given to that actor. Both [[Tom Waits]] and [[Bette Midler]] have won actions for damages against people who employed their images in advertisements that they had refused to take part in themselves.<ref name=Einhorn>{{cite book|title=Media, Technology, and Copyright: Integrating Law and Economics|author=Michael A. Einhorn|pages=121, 125|chapter=Publicity rights and consumer rights|year=2004|publisher=Edward Elgar Publishing|isbn=1-84376-657-4}}</ref>
In the USA, the use of a digital clone in advertisements is required to be accurate and truthful (section 43(a) of the [[Lanham Act]] and which makes deliberate confusion unlawful). The use of a celebrity's image would be an implied endorsement. The [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York]] held that an advertisement employing a [[Woody Allen]] impersonator would violate the Act unless it contained a disclaimer stating that Allen did not endorse the product.<ref name=Einhorn />
Other concerns include posthumous use of digital clones. [[Barbara Creed]] states that "Arnold's famous threat, 'I'll be back', may take on a new meaning". Even before Brandon Lee was digitally reanimated, the [[California Senate]] drew up the Astaire Bill, in response to lobbying from [[Fred Astaire]]'s widow and the [[Screen Actors Guild]], who were seeking to restrict the use of digital clones of Astaire. Movie studios opposed the legislation, and as of 2002 it had yet to be finalized and enacted. Several companies, including Virtual Celebrity Productions, have purchased the rights to create and use digital clones of various dead celebrities, such as [[Marlene Dietrich]]<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1999/aug/09/business/fi-64043 Los Angeles Times / Digital Elite Inc.]</ref> and [[Vincent Price]].<ref name=Creed />
== In fiction == *''[[S1m0ne]]'', a [[2002 in film|2002]] [[science fiction]] [[drama film]] written, produced and directed by [[Andrew Niccol]], starring [[Al Pacino]]. *''[[The Congress (2013 Film)]]'' a [[2013 in film|2013]] [[science fiction]] [[drama film]] written, produced and directed by [[Ari Folman]], starring [[Robin Wright]] deals with this issue extensively.

== Further reading == * {{Cite book|title=Scott on Multimedia Law|author=Michael D. Scott and James N. Talbott|chapter=Titles and Characters|year=1997|publisher=Aspen Publishers Online|isbn=1-56706-333-0}} — a detailed discussion of the law, as it stood in 1997, relating to virtual humans and the rights held over them by real humans * {{Cite book|title=Emerging Technologies and the Law: Forms and Analysis|author=[[Richard Raysman]]|chapter=Trademark Law|pages=6–15|year=2002|publisher=Law Journal Press|isbn=1-58852-107-9}} — how trademark law affects digital clones of celebrities who have trademarked their personæ
